t: Matthew 20
The Parable of the Vineyard Workers
“For*rp the*r kingdom*r of*r heaven*r is*r like*r a*r landowner*r who*r went*r out*r early*r in*r the*r morning*r to*r hire*r workers*r for*r his*r vineyard.*r
After*r agreeing*r with*r the*r workers*r on*r one*r denarius,*r he*r sent*r them*r into*r his*r vineyard*r for*r the*r day.*r
When*r he*r went*r out*r about*r nine*r in*r the*r morning,*r he*r saw*r others*r standing*r in*r the*r marketplace*r doing*r nothing.*r
He*r said*r to*r them,*r ‘You*r also*r go*r into*r my*r vineyard,*r and*r I’ll*r give*r you*r whatever*r is*r right.’*r So*r off*r they*r went.*r
About*r noon*r and*r about*r three,*r he*r went*r out*r again*r and*r did*r the*r same*r thing.*r
Then*r about*r five*r he*r went*r and*r found*r others*r standing*r around*r and*r said*r to*r them,*r ‘Why*r have*r you*r been*r standing*r here*r all*r day*r doing*r nothing?’*r
“‘Because*rp no*r one*r hired*r us,’*r they*r said*r to*r him.*r “‘You*rp also*r go*r into*r my*r vineyard,’*r he*r told*r them.*r

When*r evening*r came,*r the*r owner*r of*r the*r vineyard*r told*r his*r foreman,*r ‘Call*r the*r workers*r and*r give*r them*r their*r pay,*r starting*r with*r the*r last*r and*r ending*r with*r the*r first.’*r
“When*rp those*r who*r were*r hired*r about*r five*r came,*r they*r each*r received*r one*r denarius.*r
So*r when*r the*r first*r ones*r came,*r they*r assumed*r they*r would*r get*r more,*r but*r they*r also*r received*r a*r denarius*r each.*r
When*r they*r received*r it,*r they*r began*r to*r complain*r to*r the*r landowner:*r
‘These*r last*r men*r put*r in*r one*r hour,*r and*r you*r made*r them*r equal*r to*r us*r who*r bore*r the*r burden*r of*r the*r day’s*r work*r and*r the*r burning*r heat.’*r
“He*rp replied*r to*r one*r of*r them,*r ‘Friend,*r I’m*r doing*r you*r no*r wrong.*r Didn’t*r you*r agree*r with*r me*r on*r a*r denarius?*r
Take*r what’s*r yours*r and*r go.*r I*r want*r to*r give*r this*r last*r man*r the*r same*r as*r I*r gave*r you.*r
Don’t*r I*r have*r the*r right*r to*r do*r what*r I*r want*r with*r what*r is*r mine?*r Are*r you*r jealous*r because*r I’m*r generous?’*r
“So*rp the*r last*r will*r be*r first,*r and*r the*r first*r last.”*r
The Third Prediction of His Death
While*p going up to Jerusalem, Jesus took the twelve disciples aside privately and said to them on the way,
“See,*r we*r are*r going*r up*r to*r Jerusalem.*r The*r Son*r of*r Man*r will*r be*r handed*r over*r to*r the*r chief*r priests*r and*r scribes,*r and*r they*r will*r condemn*r him*r to*r death.*r
They*r will*r hand*r him*r over*r to*r the*r Gentiles*r to*r be*r mocked,*r flogged,*r and*r crucified,*r and*r on*r the*r third*r day*r he*r will*r be*r raised.”*r
Suffering and Service
Then*p the mother of Zebedee’s sons approached him with her sons. She knelt down to ask him for something.
“What*r do*r you*r want?”*r he asked her. “Promise,”*p she said to him, “that these two sons of mine may sit, one on your right and the other on your left, in your kingdom.”
Jesus*p answered, “You*r don’t*r know*r what*r you’re*r asking.*r Are*r you*r able*r to*r drink*r the*r cup*r that*r I*r am*r about*r to*r drink?”*r “We*p are able,” they said to him.

He*p told them, “You*r will*r indeed*r drink*r my*r cup,*r but*r to*r sit*r at*r my*r right*r and*r left*r is*r not*r mine*r to*r give;*r instead,*r it*r is*r for*r those*r for*r whom*r it*r has*r been*r prepared*r by*r my*r Father.”*r
When*p the ten disciples heard this, they became indignant with the two brothers.
Jesus called them over and said, “You*r know*r that*r the*r rulers*r of*r the*r Gentiles*r lord*r it*r over*r them,*r and*r those*r in*r high*r positions*r act*r as*r tyrants*r over*r them.*r
It*r must*r not*r be*r like*r that*r among*r you.*r On*r the*r contrary,*r whoever*r wants*r to*r become*r great*r among*r you*r must*r be*r your*r servant,*r
and*r whoever*r wants*r to*r be*r first*r among*r you*r must*r be*r your*r slave;*r
just*r as*r the*r Son*r of*r Man*r did*r not*r come*r to*r be*r served,*r but*r to*r serve,*r and*r to*r give*r his*r life*r as*r a*r ransom*r for*r many.”*r
Two Blind Men Healed
As*p they were leaving Jericho, a large crowd followed him.
There were two blind men sitting by the road. When they heard that Jesus was passing by, they cried out, “Lord, have mercy on us, Son of David!”
The crowd demanded that they keep quiet, but they cried out all the more, “Lord, have mercy on us, Son of David!”
Jesus*p stopped, called them, and said, “What*r do*r you*r want*r me*r to*r do*r for*r you?”*r
“Lord,”*p they said to him, “open our eyes.”
Moved with compassion, Jesus touched their eyes. Immediately they could see, and they followed him.
